name: bridge
content: Not everyone likes Discord! We bridge several Discord channels with Matrix rooms so more people can join. Users on both sides see all users and messages from both. If you are using Discord, a webhook causes Matrix users to appear with an APP or BOT badge.

name: contributing
content: - How you can contribute to the Termux project:

name: devver
content: In August 2025, Google announced that they would begin requiring developers to register and to provide some amount of identity information for sideloaded apks[0]. (Sideloading includes both F-Droid installs of Termux and manual downloads from Github.) The registration process is being described as similar to making a Play Store developer account. Once in effect, Android would refuse to install apks without a signature and package name matching a registered developer. A Google exec[1] has publicly stated that there is no intent to restrict sideloading beyond this, and that there is some plan to allow you to sideload self-build apks without registration. There are no other details available.
**What does this mean for Termux? What's going to happen next?**

name: examples
content: Here's a __few__ examples of what you can do using Termux:
- synchronize or back up your files: `rdiff`, `rclone`, `rsync`, `dufs`
- use one of thousands of apps from our repository
- compile your own using many common tools
- learn the basics of the Linux command line environment

name: firstrun
content: After installing Termux and opening it, you should do the following:
**1.** `termux-change-repo` (to select a nearby mirror to get updates from):
Choose the first/topmost option on each screen. _(If that one fails, try another.)_
**2.** `pkg update && pkg upgrade` (to update your package database, then upgrade all packages)
On each prompt, press `y` and `Enter` to install newest versions available
**3.** `exit` (to exit Termux, so you can restart it yourself, all updated!)

name: goodpractices
content: - Don't ask to ask, just ask

name: h2t
content: - Learn the basics of using a Linux shell in a terminal:
- Learn more about `bash` (the most common Linux shell, and the default in Termux):

name: hacking
content: If you are asking for help using Termux to:
- access someone else's data, computers, network, or accounts without permission
- send messages, posts, or traffic to someone who doesn't want it
- install tools that are dominantly for that kind of thing, such as Kali NetHunter
Termux official communities do not provide support for these uses, and asking more than once is one of the fastest paths to a ban.
It does not matter if it's for "educational purposes".
This is a simple rule - don't argue about it.

name: hi
content: Hello and welcome! #general is a support chat and we try to stay focused on support discussion over idle chat and just saying "hi".
If you have questions about termux, please go ahead and ask them! There are a lot of people in this room and someone will answer if and when they can.
If you're just looking to chat, please try <#641650601507422218>.

name: ios
content: Termux is for Android only, but there are a few alternatives on iOS:
**Disclaimer: Termux is not associated with any of the apps above!**

name: linux
content: Depends what you mean by that. Android uses a modified Linux kernel, but programs written for desktop/server Linux environments, even for the same architecture, need to be recompiled or run in a translation layer, such as proot (<https://github.com/termux/proot-distro>). From most perspectives, you can think of Termux as a Linux distro targeted at Android, without pieces like kernels and init systems that Termux cannot provide because it is ultimately just another Android app.

Android has an incompatible filesystem layout and a unique libc and dynamic linker location, all of which require recompilation or some kind of translation or shim. Termux is also constrained to running everything as its single, unprivileged, Android-assigned user, and cannot enable programs to do anything that Termux, which is ultimately just an Android app, can't do itself. More details: <https://wiki.termux.com/wiki/Differences_from_Linux>.

name: logs
content: Help us help you! No one can see your screen, and if you need help, you may not know which pieces of text are irrelevant and which are critical.
**DON'T**: summarize, rephrase, or guess which lines are most important
**DO**: describe what your end goal is - what is the original thing you set out to do / the last step after which you'll say you're done?
**DO**: give the exact and complete command you ran, including a link to where you got it, if you didn't get it from `pkg`/`apt`/`pacman` with the default termux repos
**DO**: give the entire output you got - long press on the terminal and choose "Share transcript", or copy and paste, and be mindful of any personal info that might contain
**DO**: give all of this information with the initial question next time, instead of making someone ask you for it

name: motd
content: To hide the MOTD that shows when you start up Termux:
If you want to see it show up again:
**NOTE:** These will not work if used inside a proot / chroot / qemu environment.

name: notworking
content: Avoid the phrase "not working". It doesn't tell us anything about your problem and only wastes everyone's time. There are many, many types of "it doesn't work". Does it not run? Does it throw an error? Does it freeze? Does it crash your machine? Does it not do anything? Does it do something different from what you want? If you want us to help you, remember to *tell us **what you want it to do** and **what it does instead,*** as well as any other relevant information. An MCVE (<https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example>) can be very helpful as well.

name: npm
content: Some Node.js packages comes with executable commands which cause npm to symlink their executables to the top level of your `node_modules`, e.g via the `npx` command.
On Android, this will fail if you are using your internal storage or SD card instead of Termux's private app directory.

The easiest solution is to use Termux's home directory and create your projects there. The symlinks will succeed and everything will work normally. However, you will now be required to mostly edit your project in Termux, using terminal-based text editors like `nano`, `vim`, etc.

If you prefer to have your projects available in the SD card for easier access by external text editors so you can code outside of Termux, you can ask npm to just not symlink those executables using the command `npm install --no-bin-links <package>`. You won't be able to easily access the installed executables or the `npx` command, but you will be able to `require` the module in your code.

name: phantom
content: Termux being randomly killed and displaying `[Process completed (signal 9) - press Enter]` is a known problem. It is caused by an Android battery optimization called the phantom process killer.

<https://github.com/agnostic-apollo/Android-Docs/blob/master/en/docs/apps/processes/phantom-cached-and-empty-processes.md#commands-to-disable-phantom-process-killing-and-tldr> (link above takes you to end chapter; read the full thread for an in-depth description of what's happening)

name: pkvm
content: Starting with Android 15, some devices have a Terminal app that runs a Debian virtual machine. It is built with Android's pKVM framework, which allows apps to start virtual machines that are protected from the Android OS.
**Is it better than Termux? Will it be?**
Depends. It's a real VM, so it can do some of the things plain Termux and proots can't. For example, running docker is as easy in these VMs as it is on a standalone computer.

On the other hand, the framework doesn't provide the kind of access to Android APIs that Termux:API does, and there's no evidence that's being worked on. pKVMs are likely to be less useful for automating your phone.

It's not yet clear whether pKVM will evolve into a good option for running graphical environments. As of mid-2025, Google appears to be working on GUI support, but nothing has been promised or shipped.
There's no single answer here. It depends on what you want, and on the unknown futures of both projects.

Definitely not to make a first-party Termux. The "protected" in pKVM is that the VM is protected from your Android OS, even with root. This is valuable to companies implementing things like DRM, anti-cheat, and spoofing-resistant authentication. The Debian VM is just a happy accident for users.

name: placeholder
content: In computer programming, a placeholder is a character, word, or string of characters that temporarily takes the place of the final data.

name: playstore
content: Termux on the Play Store is a fork of an old version with additional, unmerged changes, and is not controlled by the dev team at <https://github.com/termux>. Despite its existence and version number, it is not the newest or latest version, and is significantly less functional than either the current F-Droid release or Github builds. More detail: <https://github.com/termux/termux-app/discussions/4000>
Unless you know exactly what you're doing, you should not use the Play Store fork. Install the suggested release from F-Droid <:fdroid:1020972731665235998>.
If you have currently have the Play Store fork installed and want to install an official build from F-Droid or Github, you must uninstall Termux and all companion apps first.
That means uninstalling the main app, as well as Termux:API, :Styling, :Widget, :Task, :Float, and :Boot. Termux:X11 works differently and can be left installed.
If you need help with backing up your files: <https://wiki.termux.com/wiki/Backing_up_Termux>

name: ports
content: **Reaching servers and services in Termux from outside your network**

*This is dangerous.* You must assume that any port reachable from the internet will be constantly attacked, forever, and anything left open by default or by accident, or with a guessable password, will be immediately compromised. You may not notice immediately, or ever, if this happens, and your computers may be used to hurt other people until you do. Stop here if you aren't confident you understand the risks and willing to take responsibility for getting it wrong.

Most people's home networks have dynamic public addresses and are behind at least one layer of NAT (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_address_translation>), making it impossible for incoming connections to reach your device. You can work around that by:

1. Forwarding a port from your router to your phone. This requires that you are behind a single layer of NAT, that you set up dynamic DNS (or expect it to break regularly), and that you configure a consistent local address for the device running Termux. You will need to learn all of these topics before you will be able to do this comfortably.

2. Using one of several services to tunnel a public port back to your device. These are easier to set up, but require you to pass your traffic through someone else's servers. Tailscale Funnel, ngrok, and cloudflared provide this for free.

3. Setting up a VPN. There are many ways to do this, some of which still require you to pass your traffic through someone else's servers, but a VPN keeps you and others safer from the risks of exposing things to the internet. Tailscale and ZeroTier provide this for free. (Most things people talk about called "VPNs" can't do this.)

name: problemsolving
content: > "Everybody should learn to program a computer,
> because it teaches you how to think"
Does Steve Jobs knew how to code?
Steve Wozniak, Co-founder of Apple answers:
> He wasn't an engineer and he didn't do any original design,
> but he was technical enough to alter and change and add to other designs"
- How to ask questions of hackers in a way that makes it most likely that you'll get a useful answer.

name: proot
content: A proot is a box you can run processes in. The box fakes out a number of system calls make processes inside the box believe they are running somewhere other than Termux, which makes it possible to run some programs that wouldn't work without modifications in plain Termux.

Processes inside the box see a different filesystem - usually, they see one that looks like a normal Linux root filesystem. proot will also fake out the user ID processes think they are running under, so the first process will believe it's running as root and other processes can believe they're running as new users.

That is, essentially, all it does: a proot is not a VM and is not an install of Linux. It cannot have its own kernel, kernel drivers, or systemd, and processes inside a proot cannot do *anything* outside the box that processes in plain Termux can't do. In particular, proots cannot do any of these:
- access files that Termux can't access, or mount new filesystems
- load or use additional kernel drivers
- manage or access networking beyond what Termux itself can do
- enable virtualization, docker, or any other containment mechanism requiring kernel support unavailable to Termux

name: r
content: **Problems with updating packages or installing a package?**
- `pkg update` *or* `apt update` to fix problems when installing a package
- `termux-change-repo` when you get mirror problems like
[repo failed to fetch] or [repo is not signed];
-Make sure you are __not__ using Termux from the Google Play Store;

name: rd
content: **How to learn to solve problem yourself:**
Following ^this^ should enable you to troubleshoot most of your problems!

name: rice
content: To use color schemes or fonts other than the default, get Termux:Styling from F-Droid (or GitHub, if you got your main Termux app from GitHub).
- When inside Termux, long press anywhere on the terminal.
- Click either `CHOOSE COLOR` or `CHOOSE FONT` depending on what you want to customize.
Those instructions will show some pre-included options. If you want custom options:
- Put your favorite font as font.ttf (must be a monospace font)
- Modify colors.properties to use whatever color scheme you want

name: root
content: Termux cannot help you root your phone - it's just an app. Rooting any phone requires a model-specific process, and sometimes model-specific tools. Google "<your phone model> root". If you don't find anything, it's probably not possible. It is easy to break your phone's OS by following root procedures incorrectly or by assuming instructions for a slightly different phone are close enough.

Rooting makes some specific things possible, and Termux becomes more useful for those specific things on rooted phones. If you don't know what, specifically, you need root for and why it solves that problem, *you should not root your phone*.
If you think rooting might solve a problem but aren't totally sure - ask for help!

name: saf
content: **Accessing the Termux home directory from a file manager**

Termux allows accessing its own home directory by using the Storage Access Framework, which allows applications to access files via a global file picker. If your file manager looks something like the first picture, then you don't need extra configuration: you can just click on Termux and access the home directory. If your file manager doesn't look like the first picture, you might need to install Material Files (<https://f-droid.org/en/packages/me.zhanghai.android.files>) and follow the steps on the second image.

name: termuxpc
content: Termux is an Android app. It doesn't make sense to use it on Windows or ChromeOS, and using it on BlueStacks or other Android emulators is unsupported. If you want Linux or a Linux-like environment on a PC, there are much, much better answers:

WSL is an official Windows component that allows you to run Linux distros within Windows. The default version of WSL, WSL2, is a full Linux VM with easy access to your files and the ability to run graphical Linux programs. WSL1 is still available and is not a VM, if you can't use WSL2 for any reason. <https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wsl/install>
Crostini is a ChromeOS component that provides a Linux VM with easy file access and the ability to run graphical Linux programs. <https://chromeos.dev/en/linux/setup>

name: thirdparty
content: This is a termux support space. If your issue is with a third-party project built on top of termux, we probably can't help you with it. Seek help from the author(s) of that project instead.
Third-party projects, with starting points for support where we know them:

This list isn't complete - if someone tells you a project is a derivative of termux, the same applies. If you need more help contacting the authors of a third-party project, please google it instead of asking for that here.

name: vim
content: **The best way to learn vim is by using the tutor mode that's included with vim and neovim.**
- If you're new to nvim configuration try kickstart for easy setup
- Learn more about nvim configuration with lua
- Looking for IDE like experience out of the box?

name: virtualization
content: Can run most OSes by emulating hardware. Usually slow, partly because very few Android devices have hardware virtualization extensions.

Enabling user mode emulation with PRoot's `-q` parameter uses QEMU to emulate an x86 rootfs on ARM. It's usably fast for simple programs. No peripheral emulation is performed, just CPU architecture emulation.

Best for running Windows apps. You can use this to run a binary compiled for x86/x64 with decent performance. Box86 and Box64 can only run on CPUs with matching address sizes - you can't run box86 on a 64-bit CPU or box64 on a 32-bit one. Instructions on how to use and compile Box86/64 are in their repos' `README`s.
For running proot-distro distributions with foreign architectures, see <https://github.com/termux/proot-distro#adding-distribution> for info on how to setup distribution aliases.

name: xy
content: Here's a thing that happens sometimes:
**Person A**: I'm trying to get Y to work. help
**Person A**: that didn't work. I'm actually trying to do X.
**Person B**: Y wasn't a good way to do X. I could have given you the right answer at the beginning if you'd just said you really wanted X. what you need to do is...
Don't be Person A. Pause for a minute and state your actual, final, top-level goal before talking about ways you think you can accomplish it. It'll save a lot of time and frustration.
